shogun.definition: The military dictator of Japan. The word means 'commander of a force.' Though emperors existed, shoguns held actual political and military power from 1185â€“1868.

daimyo.definition: A powerful feudal lord in Japan who controlled land and commanded samurai. Daimyo were vassals of the shogun, similar to European nobles.

samurai.definition: Japan's warrior class, bound by a code of honor called Bushido. They served daimyo and were placed above merchants and artisans in the social hierarchy.

ronin.definition: A masterless samurai. When a samurai's lord (daimyo) died or dismissed them, they became ronin â€” wanderers without status in a society defined by loyalty.

feudalism.definition: A system of government based on the exchange of land for military service. Exists in Japan, medieval Europe, and elsewhere â€” a hierarchical system with lords at top and peasants at bottom.

Bushido.definition: The samurai code of conduct, emphasizing loyalty, martial arts mastery, and honor. The word means 'the way of the warrior.' It valued death with honor over dishonored survival.

rice paddy.definition: Flooded fields used to cultivate rice. Rice paddies dominated Japan's agricultural landscape and the entire feudal economy was measured in koku â€” the rice needed to feed one person for a year.

Edo period.definition: Japan's period under Tokugawa shogunate rule (1603â€“1868). Characterized by relative peace, strict social hierarchy, isolation from foreign trade, and the flourishing of arts and culture.

Meiji Restoration.definition: Japan's dramatic modernization (1868) when the Emperor was restored to power and Japan rapidly adopted Western technology. Japan went from medieval to industrial in decades to avoid being colonized.

Tokugawa.definition: The Japanese clan that established the shogunate that ruled from 1603â€“1868. Tokugawa Ieyasu unified Japan after centuries of civil war. The period was peaceful but highly controlled.

Aztec.definition: The Mexica people of central Mexico, who built one of the largest empires in the Americas. Their capital Tenochtitlan (modern Mexico City) was one of the world's largest cities in the 1400s.

Maya.definition: An ancient Mesoamerican civilization known for sophisticated writing, mathematics (including zero), astronomy, and architecture. Maya civilization flourished from 2000 BCE to the Spanish conquest.

Iroquois Confederacy.definition: Also called the Haudenosaunee, a confederacy of six nations (Mohawk, Oneida, Onondaga, Cayuga, Seneca, Tuscarora) with a sophisticated democratic constitution called the Great Law of Peace.

pochteca.definition: Long-distance merchants of the Aztec empire who traveled far trade routes, sometimes acting as spies or diplomats. They had their own god (Yacatecuhtli) and courts.

Three Sisters.definition: Corn (maize), beans, and squash â€” planted together as a companion planting system. Corn stalks support beans, beans fix nitrogen, squash shades the ground. This system fed millions across the Americas.

Great Law of Peace.definition: The constitution of the Haudenosaunee Confederacy. Features separation of powers, impeachment, consensus decision-making, and women's right to select and remove leaders â€” centuries before European equivalents.

Cahokia.definition: A pre-Columbian city near modern St. Louis that at its peak (1100 CE) had 10,000-20,000 people â€” larger than London at the time. Its Monks Mound is larger at the base than the Great Pyramid of Giza.

bison.definition: Also called American buffalo, massive herds of bison (estimated 30-60 million) roamed the Great Plains. For Plains nations, the bison provided food, clothing, shelter, tools, and spiritual meaning.

Senate.definition: Rome's governing assembly, originally 300 patrician families, later 600 members. In the Republic it held supreme power; in the Empire it retained prestige but was subordinate to the Emperor.

plebeian.definition: Common citizens of Rome â€” the vast majority of the population. Unlike patricians (the ancient aristocracy), plebeians had fewer political rights but fought for and won significant protections over centuries.

patrician.definition: Members of Rome's original aristocratic families, holding exclusive rights to the Senate and priesthoods in early Rome. The struggle between patricians and plebeians shaped the Roman Republic.

gladiator.definition: Fighters â€” mostly enslaved people, prisoners of war, or desperately poor volunteers â€” who fought in public arenas. Most were professional athletes as much as fighters; death was not as common as popular culture suggests.

Pax Romana.definition: The 'Roman Peace' â€” roughly 200 years (27 BCEâ€“180 CE) of relative stability across the Roman Empire. Trade flourished and infrastructure was built, though this 'peace' was maintained by military force.

aqueduct.definition: Roman engineering systems that carried fresh water long distances using gravity alone. Rome's 11 aqueducts delivered 1 million cubic meters of water daily. European cities wouldn't match this for over 1,000 years after Rome's fall.

Republic.definition: Rome's government from 509â€“27 BCE, featuring the Senate, elected officials (consuls), and assemblies. The word comes from Latin 'res publica' â€” 'public affair.' The Republic gave way to the Empire under Augustus.

Caesar.definition: Originally a Roman family name (Julius Caesar). After Julius Caesar's assassination (44 BCE), the name became a title for Roman rulers. The word 'czar' (Russia) and 'kaiser' (Germany) both derive from it.

plateau.definition: A flat, elevated landform â€” like a tableland rising above surrounding terrain. The Colorado Plateau and Tibetan Plateau are famous examples. Plateaus can be created by volcanic activity, tectonic lifting, or erosion of surrounding land.

wampum.definition: Shell beads used by northeastern Native American nations as currency, diplomatic gifts, and memory records. Wampum belts recorded treaties and important events through beadwork patterns.

quipu.definition: The Incan recording system using knotted strings. Knot types, positions, and string colors encoded numbers, census data, and possibly narrative information. They served as the Inca's administrative record system.
